column2: The Northmen learned the language of the Franks and adopted their religion.
column3: The Northmen learned the language of the Franks and adopted their religion.

column2: The story of Rollo is especially interesting to us, because Rollo was the forefather of that famous Duke of Normandy who, less than a hundred and fifty years later, conquered England and brought into that country the Norman nobles with their French language and customs.
column3: The story of Rollo is especially interesting to us, because Rollo was the forefather of that famous Duke of Normandy who, less than a hundred and fifty years later, conquered England and brought into that country the Norman nobles with their French language and customs.

column2: ALFRED THE GREAT
column3: ALFRED THE GREAT

column2: KING FROM 871-901 A.D.
column3: KING FROM eight hundred seventy one to nine hundred one a d

column2: I
column3: I

column2: The Danes were neighbors of the Norwegian Vikings, and like them were fond of the sea and piracy.
column3: The Danes were neighbors of the Norwegian Vikings, and like them were fond of the sea and piracy.

column2: They plundered the English coasts for more than a century; and most of northern and eastern England became for a time a Danish country with Danish kings.
column3: They plundered the English coasts for more than a century; and most of northern and eastern England became for a time a Danish country with Danish kings.

column2: What saved the rest of the country to the Saxons was the courage of the great Saxon king, Alfred.
column3: What saved the rest of the country to the Saxons was the courage of the great Saxon king, Alfred.

column2: Alfred was the son of Ethelwulf, king of the West Saxons.
column3: Alfred was the son of Ethelwulf, king of the West Saxons.

column2: He had a loving mother who brought him up with great care.
column3: He had a loving mother who brought him up with great care.

column2: Up to the age of twelve, it is said, he was not able to read well, in spite of the efforts of his mother and others to teach him.
column3: Up to the age of twelve, it is said, he was not able to read well, in spite of the efforts of his mother and others to teach him.

column2: When Alfred was a boy there were no printed books.
column3: When Alfred was a boy there were no printed books.

column2: The wonderful art of printing was not invented until about the year 1440--nearly six hundred years later than Alfred's time.
column3: The wonderful art of printing was not invented until about the year fourteen forty--nearly six hundred years later than Alfred's time.

column2: Moreover, the art of making paper had not yet been invented.
column3: Moreover, the art of making paper had not yet been invented.

column2: Consequently the few books in use in Alfred's time were written by skillful penmen, who wrote generally on leaves of parchment, which was sheepskin carefully prepared so that it might retain ink.
column3: Consequently the few books in use in Alfred's time were written by skillful penmen, who wrote generally on leaves of parchment, which was sheepskin carefully prepared so that it might retain ink.

column2: One day Alfred's mother showed him and his elder brothers a beautiful volume which contained a number of the best Saxon ballads.
column3: One day Alfred's mother showed him and his elder brothers a beautiful volume which contained a number of the best Saxon ballads.

column2: Some of the words in this book were written in brightly colored letters, and upon many of the leaves were painted pictures of gaily-dressed knights and ladies.
column3: Some of the words in this book were written in brightly colored letters, and upon many of the leaves were painted pictures of gaily dressed knights and ladies.

column2: Oh, what a lovely book! exclaimed the boys.
column3: Oh, what a lovely book! exclaimed the boys.

column2: Yes, it is lovely, replied the mother.
column3: Yes, it is lovely, replied the mother.

column2: I will give it to whichever of you children can read it the best in a week.
column3: I will give it to whichever of you children can read it the best in a week.

column2: Alfred began at once to take lessons in reading, and studied hard day after day.
column3: Alfred began at once to take lessons in reading, and studied hard day after day.

column2: His brothers passed their time in amusements and made fun of Alfred's efforts.
column3: His brothers passed their time in amusements and made fun of Alfred's efforts.

column2: They thought he could not learn to read as well as they could, no matter how hard he should try.
column3: They thought he could not learn to read as well as they could, no matter how hard he should try.

column2: At the end of the week the boys read the book to their mother, one after the other.
column3: At the end of the week the boys read the book to their mother, one after the other.

column2: Much to the surprise of his brothers, Alfred proved to be the best reader and his mother gave him the book.
column3: Much to the surprise of his brothers, Alfred proved to be the best reader and his mother gave him the book.

column2: While still very young Alfred was sent by his father to Rome to be anointed by His Holiness, the Pope.
column3: While still very young Alfred was sent by his father to Rome to be anointed by His Holiness, the Pope.

column2: It was a long and tiresome journey, made mostly on horseback.
column3: It was a long and tiresome journey, made mostly on horseback.

column2: With imposing, solemn ceremony he was anointed by the Holy Father. Afterwards he spent a year in Rome receiving religious instruction.
column3: With imposing, solemn ceremony he was anointed by the Holy Father. Afterwards he spent a year in Rome receiving religious instruction.

column2: II
column3: two

column2: In the year 871, when Alfred was twenty-two years old, the Danes invaded various parts of England.
column3: In the year eight hundred seventy one, when Alfred was twenty two years old, the Danes invaded various parts of England.

column2: Some great battles were fought, and Alfred's elder brother Ethelred, king of the West Saxons, was killed.
column3: Some great battles were fought, and Alfred's elder brother Ethelred, king of the West Saxons, was killed.

column2: Thus Alfred became king.
column3: Thus Alfred became king.

column2: The Danes still continued to fight the Saxons, and defeated Alfred in a long and severe struggle.
column3: The Danes still continued to fight the Saxons, and defeated Alfred in a long and severe struggle.

column2: They took for themselves the northern and eastern parts of England.
column3: They took for themselves the northern and eastern parts of England.

column2: Moreover, Danes from Denmark continued to cross the sea and ravage the coast of Saxon England.
column3: Moreover, Danes from Denmark continued to cross the sea and ravage the coast of Saxon England.

column2: They kept the people in constant alarm. Alfred therefore determined to meet the pirates on their own element, the sea.
column3: They kept the people in constant alarm. Alfred therefore determined to meet the pirates on their own element, the sea.

column2: So he built and equipped the first English navy, and in 875 gained the first naval victory ever won by the English.
column3: So he built and equipped the first English navy, and in eight hundred seventy five gained the first naval victory ever won by the English.

column2: A few years after this, however, great numbers of Danes from the northern part of England came pouring into the Saxon lands.
column3: A few years after this, however, great numbers of Danes from the northern part of England came pouring into the Saxon lands.

column2: Alfred himself was obliged to flee for his life.
column3: Alfred himself was obliged to flee for his life.

column2: For many months he wandered through forests and over hills to avoid being taken by the Danes.
column3: For many months he wandered through forests and over hills to avoid being taken by the Danes.

column2: He sometimes made his home in caves and in the huts of shepherds and cowherds.
column3: He sometimes made his home in caves and in the huts of shepherds and cowherds.

column2: Often he tended the cattle and sheep and was glad to get a part of the farmer's dinner in pay for his services.
column3: Often he tended the cattle and sheep and was glad to get a part of the farmer's dinner in pay for his services.

column2: [Illustration: INVASION OF ENGLAND BY THE DANES]
column3: [Illustration: INVASION OF ENGLAND BY THE DANES]

column2: Once, when very hungry, he went into the house of a cowherd and asked for something to eat.
column3: Once, when very hungry, he went into the house of a cowherd and asked for something to eat.

column2: The cowherd's wife was baking cakes and she said she would give him some when they were done.
column3: The cowherd's wife was baking cakes and she said she would give him some when they were done.

column2: Watch the cakes and do not let them burn, while I go across the field to look after the cows, said the woman, as she hurried away. Alfred took his seat on the chimney-corner to do as he was told. But soon his thoughts turned to his troubles and he forgot about the cakes.
column3: Watch the cakes and do not let them burn, while I go across the field to look after the cows, said the woman, as she hurried away. Alfred took his seat on the chimney corner to do as he was told. But soon his thoughts turned to his troubles and he forgot about the cakes.

column2: When the woman came back she cried out with vexation, for the cakes were burned and spoiled.
column3: When the woman came back she cried out with vexation, for the cakes were burned and spoiled.

column2: You lazy, good-for-nothing man! she said, "I warrant you can eat cakes fast enough; but you are too lazy to help me bake them."
column3: You lazy, good for nothing man! she said, "I warrant you can eat cakes fast enough; but you are too lazy to help me bake them."

column2: With that she drove the poor hungry Alfred out of her house.
column3: With that she drove the poor hungry Alfred out of her house.

column2: In his ragged dress he certainly did not look like a king, and she had no idea that he was anything but a poor beggar.
column3: In his ragged dress he certainly did not look like a king, and she had no idea that he was anything but a poor beggar.

column2: III
column3: three

column2: Some of Alfred's friends discovered where he was hiding and joined him.
column3: Some of Alfred's friends discovered where he was hiding and joined him.

column2: In a little time a body of soldiers came to him and a strong fort was built by them.
column3: In a little time a body of soldiers came to him and a strong fort was built by them.

column2: From this fort Alfred and his men went out now and then and gave battle to small parties of the Danes. Alfred was successful and his army grew larger and larger.
column3: From this fort Alfred and his men went out now and then and gave battle to small parties of the Danes. Alfred was successful and his army grew larger and larger.

column2: One day he disguised himself as a wandering minstrel and went into the camp of the Danes.
column3: One day he disguised himself as a wandering minstrel and went into the camp of the Danes.

column2: He strolled here and there, playing on a harp and singing Saxon ballads.
column3: He strolled here and there, playing on a harp and singing Saxon ballads.

column2: At last, Guth'rum, the commander of the Danes, ordered the minstrel to be brought to his tent.
column3: At last, Guth'rum, the commander of the Danes, ordered the minstrel to be brought to his tent.

column2: Alfred went.
column3: Alfred went.

column2: Sing to me some of your charming songs, said Guthrum. "I never heard more beautiful music." So the kingly harper played and sang for the Dane, and went away with handsome presents.
column3: Sing to me some of your charming songs, said Guthrum. "I never heard more beautiful music." So the kingly harper played and sang for the Dane, and went away with handsome presents.

column2: But better than that, he had gained information that was of the greatest value.
column3: But better than that, he had gained information that was of the greatest value.

column2: In a week he attacked the Danish forces and defeated them with great slaughter in a battle which lasted all day and far into the night.
column3: In a week he attacked the Danish forces and defeated them with great slaughter in a battle which lasted all day and far into the night.

column2: Guthrum was taken prisoner and brought before Alfred.
column3: Guthrum was taken prisoner and brought before Alfred.

column2: Taking his harp in his hands, Alfred played and sang one of the ballads with which he had entertained Guthrum in the camp.
column3: Taking his harp in his hands, Alfred played and sang one of the ballads with which he had entertained Guthrum in the camp.

column2: The Dane started in amazement and exclaimed:
column3: The Dane started in amazement and exclaimed:

column2: You, then, King Alfred, were the wandering minstrel?
column3: You, then, King Alfred, were the wandering minstrel?

column2: [Illustration: ALFRED THE GREAT IN DANISH CAMP]
column3: [Illustration: ALFRED THE GREAT IN DANISH CAMP]

column2: Yes, replied Alfred, "I was the musician whom you received so kindly.
column3: Yes, replied Alfred, "I was the musician whom you received so kindly.

column2: Your life is now in my hands; but I will give you your liberty if you will become a Christian and never again make war on my people."
column3: Your life is now in my hands; but I will give you your liberty if you will become a Christian and never again make war on my people."

column2: King Alfred, said Guthrum, "I will become a Christian, and so will all my men if you will grant liberty to them as to me; and henceforth, we will be your friends."
column3: King Alfred, said Guthrum, "I will become a Christian, and so will all my men if you will grant liberty to them as to me; and henceforth, we will be your friends."

column2: Alfred then released the Danes, and they were baptized as Christians.
column3: Alfred then released the Danes, and they were baptized as Christians.

column2: An old road running across England from London to Chester was then agreed upon as the boundary between the Danish and Saxon kingdoms; and the Danes settled in East Anglia, as the eastern part of England was called.
column3: An old road running across England from London to Chester was then agreed upon as the boundary between the Danish and Saxon kingdoms; and the Danes settled in East Anglia, as the eastern part of England was called.

column2: Years of peace and prosperity followed for Alfred's kingdom.
column3: Years of peace and prosperity followed for Alfred's kingdom.

column2: During these years the king rebuilt the towns that had been destroyed by the Danes, erected new forts, and greatly strengthened his army and navy.
column3: During these years the king rebuilt the towns that had been destroyed by the Danes, erected new forts, and greatly strengthened his army and navy.

column2: He also encouraged trade; and he founded a school like that established by Charlemagne.
column3: He also encouraged trade; and he founded a school like that established by Charlemagne.

column2: He himself translated a number of Latin books into Saxon, and probably did more for the cause of education than any other king that ever wore the English crown.
column3: He himself translated a number of Latin books into Saxon, and probably did more for the cause of education than any other king that ever wore the English crown.
